p: When AIDS first appeared there were dire predictions of hugely increased mortality, population declines, and possible socio-economic collapse. Demographers grappled with the implications and ran models to assess what might happen (Whiteside 1998). There was evidence of falling life expectancy and birth rates, changing population structures, and growing numbers of orphans. Rates of infection tended to be higher in urban areas, especially in the informal settlements or slums. What was and remains baffling is how little notice was taken of potential demographic impacts (Smith and Whiteside 2010; Whiteside 2006; de Waal 2006).
